title: DataStax's Apache Cassandra & DSE C# Hour - Ep 15
description:
Broadcasted live on Twitch -- Watch live at https://www.twitch.tv/datastaxdevs

ABOUT DATASTAX ENTERPRISE 6

DataStax  powers  the  Right-Now  Enterprise  with  the  always-on,  distributed  cloud  database  built  on  Apache  Cassandra™  and designed for hybrid cloud. DataStax Enterprise 6 (DSE 6) includes industry-leading performance, self-driving operational simplicity, and robust analytics.

Learn more at http://www.datastax.com/products/datastax-enterprise and https://www.datastax.com/products/datastax-enterprise-6

CONNECT WITH DATASTAX

Subscribe: http://www.youtube.com/c/datastax?sub_confirmation=1 
Site: http://datastax.com 
Facebook: https://facebook.com/datastax 
Twitter: https://twitter.com/datastax | https://twitter.com/datastaxdevs
Linkedin: https://www.linkedin.com/showcase/datastaxdevs/
Twitch: https://www.twitch.tv/datastaxdevs
http://feeds.feedburner.com/datastax 
https://github.com/datastax 

ABOUT DATASTAX DEVELOPERS

On the DataStax Developers YouTube channel, you can find tutorials, webinars and much more to help you learn and stay updated with the latest information on DataStax Enterprise©.  Create an account on https://academy.datastax.com to watch our free online courses, tutorials, and more.

execution all right then we're gonna look at next steps features to build all right so that really gets us in a good position oh yeah we need to also determine the next steps around key spaces because key spaces are like tables right you have to have or not not tables they're like the database itself like if you were writing running a migration against Postgres or sequel server you'd have a database already created the migrations would then be the schema and tables being created inside that particular database with Cassandra though or data stacks Enterprise we have key spaces which then have tables created inside of that write by proxy of that we need to have that key space created though because the key space can be in flux or whatnot so we need to create how should I put it we need to create some logical criteria around key spaces even though key spaces could technically be part of the migration the issue is just like with just creating a database or destroying a database you could put that into your migration but migrations are not supposed to destroy data on migrate ups right they only destroy data on migrate down when you destroy the entire database so in this particular situation we would not want to I guess we could make key spaces part of the migration but at some point we have to change from a key space or we have to change into that key space to run the schema so it could be but on the way down if you destroy the key space you've effectively wiped out the entire thing which breaks a little bit of the notion of not I mean you you basically have to have extra permissions specifically to create and destroy key spaces just like you have to have the extra permissions to create and destroy databases if you have that capability sure that's great if not what we really need to be able to do is just designate in a migration what key space to use and then run the up and run the down with cql that's actually not that hard so yeah well we'll talk about that again on the next session because that is an interesting paradigm it's a little bit different than a database itself from a functional perspective running schema migrations but it's not so different that we couldn't put it in there but yeah that is a good topic to start off the next session on so with that I am going to let everybody go and if you want to join me later in about 15 minutes I'll actually be streaming on my own channel doing a little bit of NGO programming and other things so join me there for now this is the data stacks Apache Cassandra and DSCC sharp our signing
